metadata.sermon_title: Save Us in the Time of Trial, and Deliver Us from the Evil One
metadata.preacher: Not explicitly mentioned (likely Thomas G. Long or similar New Homiletic tradition)
metadata.sermon_start_end: The New York Times Sunday magazine had a story last week that brought me up short. The subject was political conditions in Egypt today. [...] By your endurance you will gain your lives. We shall overcome... because our Lord has overcome.
metadata.liturgical_context: Wednesday night service at Grace Church
metadata.historical_context: Post-Enlightenment, post-WWII era; mentions 20th-century genocides and South African apartheid.
metadata.notes: The sermon reflects the 'New Homiletic' emphasis on narrative and imagery.

criterion_a1_imagery.analysis: The sermon excels in creating 'mental cinema' through concrete, sensory details. By opening with the 'unspeakable prisons' of Egypt and moving to the 'tiny house in Haarlem,' the preacher avoids the trap of abstract theological discourse. Paul Scott Wilson’s 'show, don't tell' principle is evident in the description of the armor of God and the 'faint scribble' of history. The imagery is not merely decorative but serves as an 'optic' (Cilliers) to view the cosmic battle. However, some metaphors, like the 'battle line,' border on the conventional, preventing a higher score.
quotes: my courage fails utterly at the thought of days or weeks—or even a few minutes—of torture in unspeakable prisons
successfully hid many Jews in a little closet in their tiny house in Haarlem
your name will only be a faint scribble on the pages of history
strengths: Strong use of contemporary and historical narrative to ground abstract concepts.
Sensory language regarding physical suffering and safety creates empathy.
Effective 'painting' of biblical scenes (the armor, the confession before Pilate).
improvement_points: Incorporate more sensory details into the 'daily grind' section to match the intensity of the historical examples.
Avoid the slight cliché of 'rattling off words' without a more original metaphor.
Develop the 'unapproachable light' image more concretely.
criterion_a1_imagery.show_vs_tell_balance: Strongly weighted toward 'showing' in the first half; shifts to 'telling' (didactic) in the 1 Timothy section.

criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.analysis: The language demonstrates high stewardship (McEntyre). The preacher carefully navigates the shift from 'temptation' to 'trial,' explaining the Greek nuance without falling into academic jargon. There is a precise naming of human emotions—fear of torture, the 'humdrum' nature of life, and the 'habit' of church attendance. The word choice is economical and avoids the 'Canaanite' fluff often found in liturgical settings. The distinction between 'minuscule' and 'world-historical' trials shows a commitment to nuance.
quotes: I have always been pretty sure that I could do the right thing if I were faced with quick extinction, by a bullet, say, or maybe a speeding subway train
Evil is more than the sum of individual misdeeds. Evil has a life of its own.
Much of this letter is rather didactic and even pedestrian—like many of our encounters in life
strengths: Exceptional clarity in explaining complex apocalyptic theology.
Honest, non-pious language regarding personal courage and church habits.
improvement_points: The transition to the 1 Timothy list (righteousness, godliness) could be more precisely defined for a modern context.
The phrase 'the Lord's work being undone' is slightly vague compared to the rest of the text.
Ensure the 'we shall overcome' ending doesn't feel like a linguistic shortcut.
criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.jargon_analysis: Theological terms like 'apocalyptic' and 'principalities' are clearly contextualized and explained through narrative.

criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.analysis: The sermon has a steady, conversational rhythm suitable for a mid-week service. It uses rhetorical parallelisms effectively (e.g., 'partly because... partly because...'). However, the heavy reliance on long Scripture block-quotes disrupts the preacher’s own cadence. The 'flow' is interrupted by the transition from dramatic historical narrative to the more 'pedestrian' advice of the later sections. It is clearly oral language, but lacks the poetic 'legato' that would elevate it to a higher aesthetic level.
quotes: Would I have the courage... Would I have the strength... Would I be able to muster the bravery...?
Nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom; there will be great earthquakes...
Mr. Minister, you are not God. You are merely a man.
strengths: Effective use of rhetorical questions to build tension at the start.
Good variation in sentence length during the personal reflections.
The ending has a rhythmic, repetitive quality that encourages the hearer.
improvement_points: Shorten the long Scripture readings or integrate them more fluidly into the prose.
Use more alliteration or assonance to make key phrases more 'sticky'.
The middle section regarding the Enlightenment feels a bit like a lecture, lacking rhythm.
criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.paper_language_diagnosis: Oral language. It is written for the ear, though the long quotes lean toward a 'reading' style.

domain_a_poetics_of_language.summary_language: The sermon displays a high level of linguistic craftsmanship. It avoids religious clichés in favor of concrete, often jarring imagery (subway trains, Egyptian prisons). The preacher practices 'stewardship of language' by being honest about their own fears and explaining theological shifts with precision. While the rhythm is occasionally hampered by lengthy biblical citations, the overall poetics are strong, favoring 'showing' over 'telling' and maintaining a sober, Reformed aesthetic that values truth over decorative beauty.

criterion_b1_narrative_arc.analysis: The sermon follows a clear 'Lowry-esque' plot: it begins with an upsetting of equilibrium (the NYT story on torture), moves through the 'complication' of theological history (the loss of apocalyptic hope), and reaches a turning point by reframing the Lord's Prayer. The movement from 'world-historical' events to the 'daily grind' of the pews provides a necessary descent from the mountain top to the valley. However, the energy dips slightly during the 1 Timothy section before recovering in the conclusion.
quotes: The New York Times Sunday magazine had a story last week that brought me up short.
Now, all of this has been very dramatic, very world-historical. I look out at you, and I don’t think you’re worrying about being dragged before 'kings and governors'...
In a sense, every time is an apocalyptic time because every time brings trials...
strengths: Compelling 'hook' that immediately establishes what is at stake.
Logical progression from global crisis to personal discipleship.
The conclusion effectively ties the 'cosmic' back to the 'minuscule'.
improvement_points: The historical overview of the 20th century feels a bit static; it could be more narratively integrated.
The transition to the 1 Timothy passage is somewhat abrupt.
The 'climax' (the Tutu story) happens a bit too early in the structure.
criterion_b1_narrative_arc.plot_diagnosis: Dynamic journey from external observation to internal application.

criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.analysis: This is the sermon's strongest structural element. It performs a classic 'reframing' (Cilliers). The preacher takes the 'strangeness' of apocalyptic literature and makes it the only logical frame for understanding the 20th century and the modern workplace. By connecting the 'time of trial' to both the Nazi camps and 'unfair treatment of colleagues,' the preacher bridges the gap between the biblical world and the hearer's reality without domesticating the text's radicality.
quotes: The apocalyptic ideas of the New Testament seem more relevant than they used to...
This translation does give a greatly enhanced understanding of our calling to locate the prayer at the frontier...
Some of us are conflicted about unfair treatment of colleagues. Some are trying to decide whether and how to get out of a relationship.
strengths: Excellent use of 'reframing' to make the Lord's Prayer feel urgent.
Respects the 'strangeness' of the biblical text while making it accessible.
Organic connection between the 'armor of God' and modern ethical decisions.
improvement_points: Could explore the 'context' of the Egyptian Christians more deeply to avoid using them as a mere springboard.
More specific examples of 'reframing' the workplace would strengthen the final third.
Address the potential 'resistance' (Stark) of hearers who find apocalyptic language frightening.
criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.reframing_present: Yes. It reframes the 'boring' Lord's Prayer as a battle-cry at the frontier of two ages.

criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.analysis: The sermon is largely an 'open work of art' (Stark) because it asks the hearer to identify their own 'battle line.' It does not provide a neat three-step plan for courage but acknowledges the 'daily grind' and the likelihood of 'missing the target.' However, the heavy use of authoritative biblical commands and the 'we shall overcome' ending leans slightly toward a 'closed' or predictable resolution. The tension between the 'already' and 'not yet' is sustained, but the moral imperatives at the end are quite directive.
quotes: What endurance and faith are called for in your life? in our life as a community of faith?
Maybe this means something that does not sound very dramatic or courageous.
We’ll miss the target many times, but we’ll keep on aiming.
strengths: Acknowledges the ambivalence of the hearer's life (habit, refuge, seeking).
Ends with an invitation to 'aim' rather than a demand for perfection.
Leaves the 'Egyptian' question open for the hearer to ponder.
improvement_points: The final quote ('We shall overcome') is a bit of a 'happy ending' cliché that closes the tension too quickly.
Allow more space for the 'silence' of God in the face of torture mentioned at the start.
Provide more room for the hearer who feels they *cannot* stand in the time of trial.
criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.open_work_diagnosis: Mostly open; the preacher acts as a 'witness' rather than a 'judge,' though the ending is somewhat monovalent.

domain_b_dramaturgy_of_structure.summary_structure: The sermon’s macro-aesthetics are characterized by a strong narrative arc and masterful reframing. It successfully moves the hearer from the 'world-historical' horrors of Egypt and the Holocaust to the 'minuscule' trials of office politics and family reconciliation. By positioning the Lord's Prayer as a prayer for the 'frontier,' the preacher creates a dynamic space where the biblical text and modern context collide. While the ending is slightly more closed and moralistic than the opening, the overall structure sustains the tension of the 'already/not yet' effectively.

kitsch_diagnosis.analysis: The sermon is remarkably free of religious kitsch. It avoids the 'cheap comfort' that Cilliers warns against by starting with the grim reality of torture and the preacher's own admission of cowardice. It does not offer a 'happy ending' to the Egyptian Christians or the Ten Boom family (most of whom died). The 'emotion' is authentic because it is rooted in the 'pain of suffering' and the 'daily grind' rather than manufactured sentiment. The only slight brush with kitsch is the very final line, which uses a somewhat overused civil rights slogan as a liturgical 'button.'
examples_of_kitsch: The final 'We shall overcome' feels slightly like a pre-packaged emotional resolution.
The phrase 'the Lord's work' can occasionally function as a pious cliché.
authentic_moments: The admission: 'I can assure you that my courage fails utterly at the thought of... torture.'
The description of 1 Timothy as 'didactic and even pedestrian—like many of our encounters in life.'
kitsch_diagnosis.recommendation: Maintain the 'sober beauty' of the first half by ensuring the conclusion is as gritty and honest as the introduction.

space_for_grace_analysis.analysis: Space is opened for grace primarily through the 'reframing' of the human struggle. By acknowledging that we will 'miss the target many times,' the preacher moves away from pure moralism toward a dependence on the 'Savior who has taught us to pray.' The 'Space for Grace' is the 'frontier' where the human soldier is upheld by the 'Divine Actor' (Immink). However, the sermon is quite heavy on the 'battle' metaphor, which can occasionally feel more like a 'task' than a 'gift,' slightly crowding the space for pure receptivity.
space_for_grace_analysis.tension_sustained: Yes, the tension between the 'unspeakable prisons' and the 'crown of life' is held without easy answers.
space_for_grace_analysis.mystery_respected: The 'unapproachable light' of God is mentioned, keeping the mystery of the divine presence intact.
space_for_grace_analysis.moralization_vs_grace: Grace prevails, but it is a 'costly grace' that demands endurance.
space_for_grace_analysis.recommendation: Emphasize more clearly that the 'armor' is a gift provided by God, not just a set of virtues to be manufactured by the believer.

overall_aesthetics.summary: This sermon is an aesthetically robust example of the 'New Homiletic' tradition, characterized by strong imagery and a compelling narrative arc. It avoids the 'vertical' detachment of dialectical theology by grounding the Word in the sensory realities of the 20th and 21st centuries. The preacher’s use of 'reframing' is particularly effective, transforming a familiar, almost 'dead' text (the Lord's Prayer) into a living, apocalyptic cry. The aesthetic quality is found in its 'sober beauty'—it does not rely on baroque flourishes but on the sharp, honest confrontation between the 'evil one' and the 'armor of God.' While the second half becomes slightly more didactic and the ending leans toward a conventional resolution, the sermon successfully creates a 'space for grace' by honoring the complexity of human fear and the 'pedestrian' nature of daily life.
strengths_top_3: Masterful 'Reframing' of the Lord's Prayer from a domestic ritual to an apocalyptic witness.
Authentic, non-kitsch engagement with suffering and personal vulnerability.
Vivid, cinematic imagery that bridges historical genocides with the 'daily grind'.
improvement_points_top_3: Improve the musicality and rhythm of the middle sections to prevent a 'lecture' feel.
Integrate long Scripture quotes more fluidly into the preacher's own rhetorical flow.
Avoid clichéd liturgical endings in favor of more 'open' or surprising conclusions.
overall_aesthetics.comparison_with_specialists: Fits Thomas G. Long's 'Witness' model and Johan Cilliers' 'Reframing' approach.
overall_aesthetics.audience_analysis: Aesthetically appeals to 'mainline' or 'thinking' Christians who are skeptical of easy answers but hungry for a faith that addresses the 'murderous' reality of history.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Experiment with an 'open ending' that leaves the hearer in the tension of the 'frontier'.
Use more 'staccato' sentence structures during the 'battle' imagery to enhance the sense of urgency.
Deepen the 'micro-aesthetics' by finding more original metaphors for the 'daily grind'.
overall_aesthetics.conclusion: The sermon is an aesthetically successful 'event' that respects the hearer's intelligence and the text's radicality. It avoids the pitfalls of kitsch and moralism, offering instead a 'sober beauty' that is transparent toward the mystery of God's presence in a violent world. By moving from the 'New York Times' to the 'Lord's Prayer,' the preacher demonstrates that homiletic aesthetics is not about decoration, but about the 'optics' of faith.
